column4: the images are in /usr/share/wallpapers, the selected option is in gconf/dcond
Can you explain how to access that option? I think I've edited dconf once before sometime but I don't remember how.
why not set the background throught the appearance tool
I'm trying to find a way to make user-selected wallpapers show up as the unity-greeter background by default.
i think it does that with 12.04
if you know how to disable that i would appreciate knowing how

The only way I know to do this now is to manually drop the desired wallpaper into /usr/share/wallpapers, set permissions correctly, and then apply it as a desktop background. As far as I know, only the default selection of wallpapers will show in unity-greeter.
now you've got me second-guessing. Let me check

I just selected a photo from ~/Pictures, gave others read/write permissions, set it as the wallpaper through the Appearance preference pane, and it doesn't show up on unity-greeter. Any of the bundled wallpapers do, but no others, UNLESS first dropped into /usr/share/wallpapers and their owner changed to root.
thats certainly desirable. you dont want random peoples contents of $HOME being shown prior to their logging in

I understand the drawbacks of that but if users WANT to show off their wallpapers, as several on this machine do, I would like to know how to set the behavior. It's not like it's random information either, since it's something that will show any time the user is actually logged in. Anyway, maybe I'll phrase this as a new question and see if I get any bites.
obviously this wont work if they have an encrypted home
you should never overestimate your users. some idiot is going to figure out a way to make a background image of all their passwords

thats one of the things that drives me CRAZY with lightdm. they are constantly doing things to make it splashier without (a) notification and (b) a way to disable it. I dont care if my [boot manager|boot framebuffer|login screen] is pretty or not.
:-) If they did that AFTER knowing the greeter's behavior, they might deserve the consequences. But I understand the point.

except its not their consequences. its your consequences. you are evidently the admin of that system, and are ultimately responsible for the security of it. so now you have to establish a policy that says "you may not use or create backgrounds that contain sensitive information"
actually, for someone like me who is interested in getting friends and family to take ubuntu seriously in order to wean them off windows, pretty is important. First impressions matter.
a more realistic scenario might be somebody deciding to make their background a render or blueprint of some unreleased company product
yeah but lightdm has been out for over 6 months now, and we STILL cannot prevent it from showing usernames
Yeah, I'm pretty much convinced on the point about arbitrary user-selected backgrounds after thinking about it. The admin can always introduce another directory for more options if people want it.
And I agree that they really should make the greeter more configurable.
